environmental_bioconcentrations.References: (1) Connell DW et al; Chemosphere 36: 2019-2030 (1999) (2) Meylan WM et al; Environ Toxicol Chem 18: 664-672 (1999) (3) Franke C et al; Chemosphere 29: 1501-14 (1994) (4) Werner AF, Kimerle RA; Environ Toxicol Chem 1: 143-146 (1982)
environmental_bioconcentrations.Value: An estimated BCF of 38 was calculated for dodecylbenzene(SRC), using a log Kow of 8.26(1), and a regression-derived equation(2). According to a classification scheme(3), this BCF suggests bioconcentration in aquatic organisms is moderate. The BCF value of bluegill sunfish exposed to dodecylbenzene in a flow-through aquarium was 35(4).

environmental_biodegradations.References: (1) McKenna EJ, Kallio RE; pp. 73-97 in Principles and Applications in Aquatic Microbiology. Henkelekian H, Dondero NC eds. NY,NY: Wiley and Sons (1964) (2) Sariaslani FS et al; Biochem J 140: 31-45 (1974) (3) Marion CV, Malaney GW; Proc Indust Waste Cong 18: 297-308 (1964) (4) Geldhill WE et al; Environ Toxicol Chem 10: 169-78 (1991)
environmental_biodegradations.Value: Various pure cultures of bacteria were shown to degrade dodecylbenzene(1,2). An activated sludge compound was shown to oxidize dodecylbenzene during a 180 hour incubation period(3). River die-away tests have shown linear alkylbenzenes are readily biodegradable, with half-lives of 4.8 and 10.1 days for C-12 isomers in river water(4).

non_human_toxicity_excerpts.References: Clayton, G.D., F.E. Clayton (eds.) Patty's Industrial Hygiene and Toxicology. Volumes 2A, 2B, 2C, 2D, 2E, 2F: Toxicology. 4th ed. New York, NY: John Wiley & Sons Inc., 1993-1994., p. 1351
non_human_toxicity_excerpts.Value: ORAL TOXICITY...IS VERY LOW; 5 G/KG SINGLE ORAL DOSE CAUSED NO DEATHS IN RATS.

sediment_soil_concentrations.References: (1) Takada H, Ishiwatari R; Environ Sci Technol 21: 875-883 (1987)
sediment_soil_concentrations.Value: Dodecylbenzene was detected in suspended sediment from rivers in Tokyo, Japan at concns of 0.042-0.626 ug/g(1).

soil_absorption_mobility.References: (1) Connell DW et al; Chemosphere 36; 2019-2030 (1999) (2) Lyman WJ et al; Handbook of Chemical Property Estimation Methods. Washington,DC: Amer Chem Soc pp. 4-9 (1990) (3) Swann RL et al; Res Rev 85: 17-28 (1983)
soil_absorption_mobility.Value: The Koc of dodecylbenzene is estimated as 7.4X10+5(SRC), using a log Kow of 8.26(1) and a regression-derived equation(2). According to a classification scheme(3), this estimated Koc value suggests that dodecylbenzene is expected to be immobile in soil.
